After the <a href="Pekanbaru%20Railway">Pekanbaru Railway</a> was abandoned at the end of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, there is currently no active railway line in Riau. However, there has been a proposal of reactivating the Pekanbaru-West Sumatra railway to connect Pekanbaru and <a href="Padang">Padang</a> on the western coast of <a href="Sumatra">Sumatra</a>, as well as building the Pekanbaru-Duri-<a href="Rantau%20Prapat">Rantau Prapat</a> railway which would connect Riau and the existing railway line in <a href="North%20Sumatra">North Sumatra</a>, as well as building the Pekanbaru-<a href="Jambi">Jambi</a>-<a href="Betung">Betung</a>-<a href="Palembang">Palembang</a> railway which would connect Riau with Jambi and th existing railway line in <a href="South%20Sumatra">South Sumatra</a>. Overall, this railway system would form the Trans-Sumatra Railway.
Tourism.
The prime tourist attractions of Riau can be divided into natural environment, as well as the culture and history of the Riau <a href="Malays%20%28ethnic%20group%29">Malay people</a>.
Tourist attractions in Riau are diverse, ranging from marine tourism, because of the location of Riau which is directly facing the <a href="Strait%20of%20Malacca">Strait of Malacca</a>. And also natural tourism is equally attractive when compared to other provinces in Sumatra. This province has a long history and is present throughout the province, thus making its historical and cultural tourism diverse and well-known.
Each of the regencies in Riau has a tourist attraction within.
The <a href="Indragiri%20Hilir%20Regency">Indragiri Hilir Regency</a> has a long story before the Dutch colonial period. Quite a lot of power shifts while still in the kingdom. Starting from Keritang Kingdom, Kemuning Kingdom, Batin Enam Suku Kingdom to Indragiri Kingdom. besides having an interesting history, Indragiri Hilir Regency also has interesting tourist attractions, and one of them is Solop Beach which is also a mainstay of tourist attractions in Riau. As Indragiri Hilir was once the seat of the Indragiri Sultanate, there are many relics from the sultanate than can be still found throughout the region, such as the Indragiri Kings Cemetery in <a href="Rengat">Rengat</a> and traditional houses with typical Malay architecture. Moreover, Indragiri Hilir is also known for its many waterfalls. Similar to Indragiri Hilir, the <a href="Indragiri%20Hulu%20Regency">Indragiri Hulu Regency</a> is filled of many tourism spots, such as waterfalls and relic of ancient Malay kingdoms. Furthermore, Indragiri Hulu also serves as the gateway to the <a href="Bukit%20Tigapuluh%20National%20Park">Bukit Tigapuluh National Park</a>.
The location of <a href="Kampar%20Regency">Kampar Regency</a> which is directly adjacent with the province of <a href="West%20Sumatra">West Sumatra</a> allows its culture to be greatly influenced by the culture of the <a href="Minangkabau%20people">Minangkabau people</a>. Kampar Regency also has some famous and historical attractions, such as the <a href="Muara%20Takus">Muara Takus</a> Buddhist Temple. There are also many spectacular waterfalls spread throughout Kampar. Moreover, there are also tombs of Malay and Minangkabau kings in Kampar. The city of <a href="Bangkinang">Bangkinang</a> has many tourist attractions that have nuances of nature, history, religion and culinary that cannot be found in any parts of Indonesia.
The <a href="Kepulauan%20Meranti%20Regency">Kepulauan Meranti Regency</a> has a variety of marine tourism destinations. Therefore, making it one of the biggest contributors to tourist attractions in Riau that attract both domestic and international tourists each year. The capital <a href="Selat%20Panjang">Selat Panjang</a> has a <a href="Chinese%20Indonesians">Chinese</a>-majority population, making it one of the few cities to have this characteristic. This explains why the culture of Selat Panjang as well as the whole of Kepulauan Meranti is highly influenced by both Chinese and Malay culture. Moreover, there are several Chinese temples that can be found in Selat Panjang and the surrounding area, including the <a href="Hoo%20Ann%20Kiong%20Temple">Hoo Ann Kiong Temple</a>, which so the oldest Chinese <a href="Taoism">Taoism</a> temple in <a href="Selat%20Panjang">Selat Panjang</a>.
<a href="Kuantan%20Singingi%20Regency">Kuantan Singingi Regency</a>, commonly known as Kuansing, is a "rantau" (migration) area for the <a href="Minangkabau%20people">Minangkabau people</a> from <a href="West%20Sumatra">West Sumatra</a>. Therefore, the culture and customs of Kuansing is highly influenced by Minangkabau culture. On the other hand, Kuansing also contains many tourist destinations. Kuansing is known for its cultural festival that usually happens during the <a href="Eid%20al-Fitr">Eid al-Fitr</a> and other holidays such as the Baganduang Boat Festival (<a href="Indonesian%20language">Indonesian</a>: "Festival Perahu Baganduang"). The Baganduang Boat Festival was first held as a festival in 1996. These boats are then decorated with flags, coconut leaves, umbrellas, long cloths, pumpkins, photos of the president and vice president, and other objects that have traditional symbols. For example, rice symbolizes agricultural fertility and buffalo horns that symbolize livestock. In the festival, guests were presented with a variety of entertainment, including "Rarak Calempong", "Panjek Pinang", and "Potang Tolugh". The process of making a baganduang boat is usually blessed with a Malay ceremony. Another festival in Kuansing is the <a href="Pacu%20Jalur">Pacu Jalur</a> Festival. Pacu Jalur is the largest annual festival for the people of the <a href="Kuantan%20Singingi%20Regency">Kuantan Singingi Regency</a>, especially in the capital, Taluk Kuantan, which is along the bank of the <a href="Indragiri%20River">Kuantan River</a>. Originally, the festival was held to commemorate the Islamic holidays such as the <a href="Mawlid">Mawlid</a>, or the commemoration of the New Year's Eve. But after the <a href="Proclamation%20of%20Indonesian%20Independence">Indonesian independence</a>, Pacu Jalur is now usually held to celebrate the Independence Day of the Republic of Indonesia. Pacu Jalur is a long rowing boat race, similar to the <a href="Dragon%20Boat%20Festival">Dragon Boat</a> race in neighboring <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> and Singapore, which is a boat or canoe made of wood that can reach 25 to 40 meters in length. In the Taluk Kuantan area, the native people called the longboat used in the festival as "Jalur". The boat rower team ranges from 50 to 60 people.
<a href="Pelalawan%20Regency">Pelalawan Regency</a> has a long history, even as the name Pelalawan was taken from the name of the former Pelalawan Kingdom. And the Pelalawan Kingdom was once victorious in 1725 and was very famous with its Sultan Syed Abdurrahman Fachrudin. Apart from its history, Pelalawan also stores quite a lot of tourist attractions besides its history. Remnants of the old Pelalawan Kingdom can still be seen throughout the regency, such as Sayap Pelalawan palace where the former Sultan of Pelalawan reside. Inside the Pelalawan Wing Palace there are many relics, such as keris weapons, spears, and various other relics placed in the palace central room. Another remnants is tomb of the <a href="sultan">sultan</a>s of Pelalawan. Most of the tourist who frequented the tomb are usually pilgrims and certain days the tomb is quite crowded with pilgrims. Moreover, Pelalawan serves as the gateway to the <a href="Tesso%20Nilo%20National%20Park">Tesso Nilo National Park</a>.
<a href="Rokan%20Hilir%20Regency">Rokan Hilir Regency</a> as one of the regencies in Riau which is directly facing the <a href="Strait%20of%20Malacca">Strait of Malacca</a>, was once the largest fish producer in Indonesia. Since the Dutch colonial era, Rokan Hilir with its capital <a href="Bagansiapiapi">Bagansiapiapi</a> has already become more advanced than other region especially in terms of trade. The tourism industry in Rokan Hilir is also quite well known both on a national and international scale. Rokan Hilir is known for its tourist spots and festival such as the Junk burning festival. Known in the local <a href="Southern%20Peninsular%20Malaysian%20Hokkien">Riau Hokkien</a> as "Go Gek Cap Lak" (Chinese: 五月十六日; <a href="pinyin">pinyin</a>: "wǔ yuè shíliù rì"; <a href="Hokkien">Hokkien</a> <a href="Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB">POJ</a>: "gō͘-go̍eh-cha̍p-la̍k-ji̍t"), the <a href="Junk%20%28ship%29">Junk</a> burning festival is an annual ritual of the community in Bagansiapiapi which has been well known overseas and is included in the Indonesian tourism tourist. Every year this ritual can attract tourists from <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>, Singapore, <a href="Thailand">Thailand</a>, <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> to <a href="Mainland%20China">Mainland China</a>. Now this annual event is heavily promoted by the government of Rokan Hilir Regency as a source of tourism. The initial history of the festival was started by Chinese people who lived in Bagansiapiapi to commemorate their ancestors and also as a gesture of gratitude to the God Kie Ong Ya. Other than that, Bagansiapiapi and the surrounding area has many Chinese temples that can be visited.
The <a href="Rokan%20Hulu%20Regency">Rokan Hulu Regency</a> has the nickname "Negeri Seribu Suluk". The district is bordered by two provinces, namely <a href="North%20Sumatra">North Sumatra</a> and <a href="West%20Sumatra">West Sumatra</a>. It is certain that the acculturation of culture in Rokan Hulu Regency has become more diverse, starting from customs and traditions. Rokan Hulu contains many lakes, waterfalls and caves that is spread throughout the region. One of the historical assets that is still standing firmly in Rokan Hulu, is the <a href="Palace%20of%20Rokan%20Hulu">Palace of Rokan Hulu</a>. This palace, which is already 200 years old, is a relic of the Nagari Tuo Sultanate. Although there are some parts of the repair but the architecture is still intact and also the carvings on the wood are still clearly visible.
<a href="Siak%20Regency">Siak Regency</a> is the number two richest district in Riau after <a href="Bengkalis%20Regency">Bengkalis Regency</a>. The main export of Siak Regency is petroleum which finally can deliver it to become the second richest regency in the province. On the other hand, the regency is currently boosting the tourism sector to attract more visitors. As Siak was once the house of the <a href="Sultanate%20of%20Siak%20Sri%20Indrapura">Sultanate of Siak Sri Indrapura</a>, the regency contains remnants of the sultanate that is still well-preserved, such as the <a href="Siak%20Sri%20Indrapura%20Palace">Siak Sri Indrapura Palace</a>. The palace complex has an area of about 32,000 square meters consisting of 4 palaces namely Istana Siak, Istana Lima, Istana Padjang, and Istana Baru. Each of the palace including "Siak Palace" itself has an area of 1,000 square meters. The palace contains royal ceremonial objects, such as a gold-plated crown set with diamonds, a golden throne and personal objects of Sultan Syarif Qasyim and his wife, such as the "Komet", a multi-centennial musical instrument which is said to have been made only two copies in the world. Presently, the "komet" is still functioning and is used to play works by composers such as <a href="Ludwig%20van%20Beethoven">Beethoven</a>, <a href="Wolfgang%20Amadeus%20Mozart">Mozart</a> and <a href="Richard%20Strauss">Strauss</a>. Siak is also home to the tomb of <a href="Sultan%20Syarif%20Kasim%20II">Sultan Syarif Kasim II</a>, the last Sultan of Siak.
<a href="Dumai">Dumai</a> is a city located in Riau whose location is very strategic especially for international trade because of its location in the <a href="Strait%20of%20Malacca">Strait of Malacca</a>. In addition, Dumai is the largest city in Indonesia at this time. Dumai is home to many beaches and mangrove forests.
The capital of Riau, <a href="Pekanbaru">Pekanbaru</a>, contains several tourist attractions. The Idrus Tintin Art Building is named after an Indonesian artist named Idrus Tintin. Judging from the architecture of the Idrus Tintin Art Building almost looks like a Malay Royal Palace, even though this building functioned as an art performance venue. Various works by Indonesian artists are displayed in the building. The <a href="An-Nur%20Great%20Mosque%20Pekanbaru">An-Nur Great Mosque</a> is the pride of Pekanbaru. An-Nur Great Mosque is one of the grandest mosques in Indonesia. An-Nur Great Mosque was built in 1968 from the side of its architecture which is similar to the <a href="Taj%20Mahal">Taj Mahal</a> in India. Therefore, many people Riau called the mosque as the "Taj Mahal of Riau". <a href="Soeman%20Hs%20Library">Soeman H.S Library</a> is named after <a href="Soeman%20Hs">Soeman H.S</a>, a novelist from Riau and his name is immortalized as the name of the library in downtown Pekanbaru. The <a href="architectural%20style">architectural style</a> of the building is similar to open books or like a <a href="Rehal%20%28book%20rest%29">"rehal"</a> (placemats for the <a href="Quran">Qur'an</a>). This tourist spot in Riau has quite a collection of books, and has even been the largest library in Asia.
Cuisine.
The cuisine of Riau is heavily influenced by <a href="Malay%20cuisine">Malay</a> and <a href="Padang%20cuisine">Minangkabau</a> cuisines, and also slightly influenced by <a href="Chinese%20cuisine">Chinese</a> and <a href="Javanese%20cuisine">Javanese cuisine</a>s. The cuisine in Riau is somewhat similar to the cuisine in the <a href="Malay%20Peninsula">Malay Peninsula</a> across the <a href="Strait%20of%20Malacca">Strait of Malacca</a>.
Traditional Malay cuisine in Riau has much in common with other Malay cuisines in other part of the <a href="Malay%20world">Malay world</a> and Sumatran cuisine which generally uses spices and <a href="coconut%20milk">coconut milk</a> to produce spicy, fatty and thick <a href="curry">curry</a>.. Most dishes use basic ingredients of fish, from <a href="pangasius">pangasius</a>, <a href="mystus">mystus</a>, <a href="anchovy">anchovy</a>, <a href="Spanish%20mackerel">Spanish mackerel</a>s, <a href="Manta%20ray">rays</a>, and <a href="prawn">prawn</a>s, and often uses <a href="Water%20buffalo">buffalo</a> or ox meat. Additional ingredients commonly used are <a href="Shrimp%20paste">Belacan</a>. Almost every Malay dish is served with white rice or with "<a href="nasi%20lemak">nasi lemak</a>" and is usually eaten using hands.
"Nasi Lemak" is a typical Riau food in the form of rice cooked with coconut milk to provide a savory flavor and fragrant aroma. "Nasi Lemak" is generally served with side dishes such as eggs, fried anchovy, chili sauce, cucumber slices and other side dishes. This "nasi lemak" is easily found in stalls and restaurants in <a href="Pekanbaru">Pekanbaru</a>. In archipelagic region like <a href="Riau%20Islands">Riau Islands</a> province of <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, usually seafood are used to accompany nasi lemak, such as "ikan bilis" (<a href="anchovy">anchovy</a>), "ikan tamban" ("<a href="Sardinella%20longiceps">Sardinella longiceps</a>"), "ikan selar kuning" ("<a href="Selaroides%20leptolepis">Selaroides leptolepis</a>"), "sotong" or "cumi-cumi" (squid) or small <a href="prawn">prawn</a>s. The Riau islands traditional nasi lemak is quite similar to Malaysian version; it comes as a platter of coconut rice wrapped in banana leaf, with cucumber slices, small dried anchovies ("ikan bilis"), roasted peanuts, hard boiled egg, and hot spicy sauce ("sambal"). The Riau islands version however, comes with an addition of small fish locally known as "ikan tamban", usually fried with "<a href="sambal">sambal</a>" chili paste and very crispy, the whole fish is edible. <a href="Prawn">Prawn</a>s and <a href="squid">squid</a>s are also commonly stir-fried in chili paste as "sambal udang" or "sambal cumi". In Indonesia, nasi lemak is often sprinkled with "bawang goreng" (crispy fried <a href="shallot">shallot</a> granules). In <a href="Pekanbaru">Pekanbaru</a> city in Sumatran province of Riau however, freshwater river fishes are commonly used as "lauk" to accompany nasi lemak. The freshwater fishes includes "ikan selais" ("<a href="Kryptopterus%20cryptopterus">Kryptopterus cryptopterus</a>") and "ikan patin" ("<a href="Pangasius">Pangasius</a>"). Other fish such as "ikan lomek" ("<a href="Harpadon%20nehereus">Harpadon nehereus</a>") is also commonly used. These fishes are usually cooked in <a href="Padang%20food">Minang</a> style "lado ijo" (green chili pepper), minced and fried as "perkedel ikan", or just plainly fried.
The "<a href="Gulai">Gulai</a> Ikan Patin" (<a href="Catfish">Catfish</a> soup) has a very delicious and powerful taste and it can be easily be found around Pekanbaru. "Gulai Ikan Patin" is a typical Pekanbaru food that has a deep yellow sauce to soak the pieces of catfish. The people of Riaum especially Pekanbaru, generally also consume other ingredients other than the catfish. There are sidedishes accompanying the dish, such as boiled yams, leaf tops and more. "Gulai Ikan Patin" is usually cooked with the "<a href="etlingera%20elatior">etlingera elatior</a>" to enhance the flavouring.
"<a href="Asam%20pedas">Asam pedas</a>" (or "Asam padeh" in <a href="Minangkabau%20people">Minangkabau</a>) is a Malay-Minangkabau dish that can be found in Riau and the surrounding area.. It is a type sour and spicy fish stew dish. The main ingredients in "asam pedas" are usually seafood or freshwater fish. They are cooked in "asam" (<a href="tamarind">tamarind</a>) fruit juice with <a href="Chili%20pepper">chilli</a> and spices. The cooking process involves soaking the pulp of the tamarind fruit until it is soft and then squeezing out the juice for cooking the fish. "Asam" paste may be substituted for convenience. Vegetables such as "terong" or "brinjals" (Indian <a href="eggplant">eggplant</a>s), <a href="okra">okra</a> and tomatoes are added. Fish and seafood – such as <a href="mackerel">mackerel</a>, <a href="Euthynnus%20affinis">mackerel tuna</a>, <a href="tuna">tuna</a>, <a href="skipjack%20tuna">skipjack tuna</a>, <a href="Red%20snapper%20%28fish%29">red snapper</a>, <a href="gourami">gourami</a>, <a href="pangasius">pangasius</a>, <a href="hemibagrus">hemibagrus</a> or <a href="cuttlefish">cuttlefish</a> – either the whole body or sometimes only the <a href="Fish%20head%20curry">fish heads</a> are added to make a spicy and tart <a href="fish%20stew">fish stew</a>. It is important that the fish remain intact for serving so generally the fish is added last. In the Riau region, the most common fish used in asam pedas is "<a href="Euthynnus%20affinis">tongkol</a>" (mackerel tuna).
Aside from the main dish, typical Riau restaurant also serves local snacks. An example is the "<a href="roti%20jala">roti jala</a>". "Roti jala" typical Riau food which is influenced by <a href="Malay%20culture">Malay culture</a>. "Roti jala" is a dish that is generally present at large parties such as weddings. This food is made from the basic ingredients of flour which, after being cooked, will be served with a spill of durian sauce for those who like sweet foods. Aside from being served with sauce, "roti jala" is also commonly eaten with curry chicken, mutton or beef. "Roti jala" has a triangular shape that is produced from a mold. Although it is usually white in color, some creative cooker also gives food coloring such as "<a href="pandanus">pandanus</a>" to make the "roti jala" green in color. "<a href="Roti%20canai">Roti cane</a>" is a typical Riau food. This bread has much in common with "<a href="Roti%20prata">roti pratha</a>" in <a href="India">India</a> and Singapore aside from the taste and eating method.
Sports.
Riau has a football team, <a href="PSPS%20Pekanbaru">PSPS Pekanbaru</a>, based in <a href="Rumbai%20Stadium">Kaharuddin Nasution Stadium</a>, Pekanbaru. There is also has local football team <a href="PS%20Siak">PS Siak</a>. In 2012, Riau hosted <a href="Pekan%20Olahraga%20Nasional">Pekan Olahraga Nasional</a>.
